redcap:SurveysScheduler.email_content:
Please take this survey.

You may open the survey in your web browser by clicking the link below:
[survey-link]

If the link above does not work, try copying the link below into your web browser:
[survey-url]

This link is unique to you and should not be forwarded to others.

redcap:SurveysScheduler.email_subject: P.K. Yonge COVID-19 Study - Household Questionnaire
redcap:SurveysScheduler.email_content:
Dear Students and Families of the P.K. Community,Â 

Â 

Thank you for your participation in the PKY COVID-19 Study. With this email, we invite you to complete the online questionnaire and sign-up for testing, which will be conducted from April 19-22. The unique link for [ce_firstname] [ce_lastname] is provided at the end of this email.

Â 

Please note, if you have more than one child enrolled in the study, you will receive an email invitation and unique link for each child to sign up for testing. If you are a household contact, this is your unique link to sign up for testing.

Â 

We are only able to provide testing for those who have consented to participation online ahead of time. There will be no on-site consent or registration.

Â 

Your participation is completely voluntary, and we are pleased to offer a $20 gift card for each participant in this round of data collection.

Â 

Once you click on the link you'll be asked to:

1) Complete an online survey

2) Select an appointment time

3) Arrive at P.K. Yonge at your designated appointment time and place

4) Have the coronavirus test administered

Â  Â  Â * a throat swab

Â  Â  Â * a finger stick blood sample

Â 

Participants may be asked to participate in a follow-up study, which may include phone interviews, online surveys, or sample collection. Further participation is not required.

Â 

Here is [ce_firstname] [ce_lastname]'s unique link:

[survey-link]

If the link above does not work, try copying the link below into your web browser:
[survey-url]

Â 

Thank you for being a partner in this research.

Â 

Drs. Sarah McKune, Eric Nelson, and Tony Maurelli, on behalf of the COVID-19 P.K. Yonge study team

Â 

Clinical questions? Please contact school nurse Eva Gonzalez | nurse@pky.ufl.edu or Dr. Eric Nelson at (352) 294-8536.

Other question? Please contact the study team at this email or Dr. Sarah McKune at (352) 328-0615.

redcap:SurveysScheduler.email_subject: P.K. Yonge COVID-19 Study - Student Questionaire

Dear Students and Families of the P.K. Community,Â 

Â

redcap:Alerts.alert_message:
Dear [ce_firstname] [ce_lastname],

Â 

This email serves as the confirmation of your appointment to get COVID 19 testing being offered by the University of Florida.

Â 

Your appointment is scheduled for: [test_date_and_time]

Â 

Your appointment ID: [research_encounter_id]

Â 

Please note that you are being tested for RESEARCH.Â  That means that you will be tested with supplies and test kits provided by The University of Florida Emerging Pathogens Institute Lab.Â  These kits have not yet received FDA or CDC approval, but have been demonstrated to be robust. Results of your swab tests will be provided to you via email or phone within 4-5 business days.Â  Since this is a research test, you may want to confirm your test results via standard CDC testing as more of these tests become available.Â 

Â 

In order to be eligible for your appointment, you must arrive to the testing site location within 5-10 minutes of your assigned appointment time.Â 

Â 

The testing site is located at:Â 1080 SW 11th St, Gainesville, FL 32601Â (P.K. Yonge). Directions will be provided at the front gate.Â 

Â 

When you arrive, please proceed to the P.K. Yonge Front Circle & DO NOT leave your vehicle.

Â 

You will need to bring:

Â 

  • A photo ID
  • Studentâs PK Yonge photo ID
  • A copy of this confirmation email printed, or on your phone

Â 

Please make sure that your child is well hydrated on the morning you bring them for testing. This will facilitate sample collection.

Â 

We look forward to assisting you,

Â 

UF Health

redcap:Alerts.email_subject: Confidential: UF Health Research Test Results
redcap:Alerts.alert_message:
Dear [icf_email],

Â The result of [ce_firstname] [ce_lastname]âs research coronavirus antibody test from the UF-EPI COVID screening during time point four data collection in April 2021 is negative. This means that the test did not detect antibodies (IgG) to the virus that causes COVID-19 in your childâs dried blood spot sample.

Â Because of the medical communityâs limited understanding of the human immune response to the COVID-19 virus, we cannot say how these negative results influence [ce_firstname] [ce_lastname]âs susceptibility to infection. It is also not known how much time it takes to generate an antibody response after infection. Therefore, if your child had COVID-19 shortly before the sample was collected your body may not have had time to make sufficient antibodies for a positive result.

Â We urge you to continue practicing ways to reduce your exposure to the virus or to transmitting the virus to others:

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Avoid touching your eye, nose, and mouthÂ 

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Practice physical distancing from others to limit the spread of germs

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surface

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Wear a mask in indoor public places and follow your communityâs mask recommendations

Â If you develop mild symptoms of fever, cough, or shortness of breath, call your primary care provider or occupational health physician for guidance on examination and testing. Should you develop moderate or severe symptoms, please do not hesitate to seek medical care, call 911, or present to your local emergency department.

Thank you for participating in the UF-EPI COVID-19 Research study at P. K. Yonge.

redcap:Alerts.email_subject: Confidential: UF Health Research Test Results
redcap:Alerts.alert_message:
Dear [icf_email],

Â The result of [ce_firstname] [ce_lastname]âs research coronavirus antibody test from the UF-EPI COVID screening collected during time point four data collection in April 2021 is indeterminate.Â This means that the test could not provide a definitive YES or NO result on the detection of antibodies (IgG) to the COVID-19 in your (your childâs) sample.

Because of the medical communityâs limited understanding of the human immune response to the COVID-19 virus, we cannot say how this result influences your childâs susceptibility to infection. It is also not known how much time it takes to generate an antibody response after infection. Therefore, if [ce_firstname] [ce_lastname] had COVID-19 shortly before the sample was collected, [ce_firstname] [ce_lastname] body may not have had time to make sufficient antibodies for a positive result.

Â We urge you to continue practicing ways to reduce your exposure to the virus or to transmitting the virus to others:

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Avoid touching your eye, nose, and mouthÂ 

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Practice physical distancing from others to limit the spread of germs

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surface

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Wear a mask in indoor public places and follow your communityâs mask recommendations

Â If you develop mild symptoms of fever, cough, or shortness of breath, call your primary care provider or occupational health physician for guidance on examination and testing. Should you develop moderate or severe symptoms, please do not hesitate to seek medical care, call 911, or present to your local emergency department.

Thank you for participating in the UF-EPI COVID-19 Research study at P. K. Yonge.

redcap:Alerts.email_subject: Confidential: UF Health Research Test Results
redcap:Alerts.alert_message:
Dear [icf_email],

The result of [ce_firstname] [ce_lastname]'s research coronavirus test from the UF Emerging Pathogens Institute COVID-19 screening conducted during time point four data collection in April of 2021 is NEGATIVE. This means that the test did not detect coronavirus in the specimen that was collected from your child.

These negative research test results do not mean that [ce_firstname] [ce_lastname] is not infected or wonât become infected with coronavirus in the future, if exposed. The reason is that it is possible to have false negative results (says negative but actually positive); although the chance of this event is expected to be low. Therefore, we urge you to continue practicing ways to reduce your familyâs exposure to the virus or to transmitting the virus to others:

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Avoid touching your eye, nose, and mouth

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Practice physical distancing from others to limit the spread of germs

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Wear a face mask (cloth, reserving medical masks for health care providers) when in a public space, such as a grocery store

If anyone develops symptoms of fever, cough, or shortness of breath, call his/her pediatrician or primary care provider for guidance on examination and testing. Should s/he develop moderate or severe symptoms, please do not hesitate to seek medical care, call 911, or present to your local emergency department.

Thank you for all that you do for the community, and thank you for participating in the UF Emerging Pathogens Institute COVID-19 Research screening protocol.

redcap:Alerts.email_subject: Confidential: UF Health Research Test Results
redcap:Alerts.alert_message:
Dear [icf_email],

The result of [ce_firstname] [ce_lastname]'s research coronavirus test from the UF Emerging Pathogens Institute COVID-19 screening conducted during time point four data collection in April of 2021 is NEGATIVE. This means that the test did not detect coronavirus in the specimen that was collected from your child.

These negative research test results do not mean that [ce_firstname] [ce_lastname] is not infected or wonât become infected with coronavirus in the future, if exposed. The reason is that it is possible to have false negative results (says negative but actually positive); although the chance of this event is expected to be low. Therefore, we urge you to continue practicing ways to reduce your familyâs exposure to the virus or to transmitting the virus to others:

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Avoid touching your eye, nose, and mouth

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Practice physical distancing from others to limit the spread of germs

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Wear a face mask (cloth, reserving medical masks for health care providers) when in a public space, such as a grocery store

If anyone develops symptoms of fever, cough, or shortness of breath, call his/her pediatrician or primary care provider for guidance on examination and testing. Should s/he develop moderate or severe symptoms, please do not hesitate to seek medical care, call 911, or present to your local emergency department.

Thank you for all that you do for the community, and thank you for participating in the UF Emerging Pathogens Institute COVID-19 Research screening protocol.

redcap:Alerts.email_subject: Confidential: UF Health Research Test Results
redcap:Alerts.alert_message:
Dear [icf_email],

The result of [ce_firstname] [ce_lastname]'s research coronavirus test from the UF Emerging Pathogens Institute COVID-19 screening conducted during time point four data collection in April of 2021 is POSITIVE. This means that the test did detect coronavirus in the specimen that was collected from your child.

These positive research test results mean that [ce_firstname] [ce_lastname] is infected with coronavirus. The reason is that it is possible to have false negative results (says negative but actually positive); although the chance of this event is expected to be low. Therefore, we urge you to continue practicing ways to reduce your familyâs exposure to the virus or to transmitting the virus to others:

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Avoid touching your eye, nose, and mouth

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Practice physical distancing from others to limit the spread of germs

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Clean and disinfect frequently touched objects and surfaces

â¢Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Wear a face mask (cloth, reserving medical masks for health care providers) when in a public space, such as a grocery store

If anyone develops symptoms of fever, cough, or shortness of breath, call his/her pediatrician or primary care provider for guidance on examination and testing. Should s/he develop moderate or severe symptoms, please do not hesitate to seek medical care, call 911, or present to your local emergency department.

Thank you for all that you do for the community, and thank you for participating in the UF Emerging Pathogens Institute COVID-19 Research screening protocol.

MetaDataVersion.Name: PK Yonge COVID-19 Timepoint 4 Surveys - Production

ItemGroupDef.Name: SECTION A) ALL PARTICIPANTS, PARENT QUESTIONS (PARENTS COMPLETE THIS SECTION ONLY ONCE PER HOUSEHOLD)

Thank you for participating as a household contact to a student participating in our COVID-19 study at P.K. Yonge. In the questions below "you" refers to the household contact. This may be you, or it may be an additional child in your household, such as a younger brother or sister of the participating student.
CHART REVIEW/LABORARTORY STUDIES (To be completed by Study Staff)

Question.TranslatedText:
We very much appreciate your participation in the COVID-19 screening conducted at P.K. Yonge, in partnership with researchers at the University of Florida. The screening is being done as part of a research protocol, to allow us to gain a better understanding of why certain people become infected - and among those who are infected, for how long they are infected with the virus, even if they are asymptomatic. There is still a great deal that we do not know about COVID-19, and your continued participation in this study will be of great value as we try to learn how best to protect people from this virus.
As a starting point, we would like to ask you some basic questions about your child's health and possible exposures, as well as your current understanding of the virus, how it spreads, and what you are doing to reduce risk. We will also collect some information on how the current state of the pandemic is affecting you and your family in terms of stress and your current coping strategies. It will take about 20-30 minutes to complete the questionnaire, and all information obtained will be kept strictly confidential, as outlined in the consent form that you signed. We would then like to contact you again, in about 1 month, and again at 6 months and 1 year, to see how your child is doing, and if your child became ill during the intervening time period. This will help us to identify specific risk factors for infection or severe disease. If you would prefer not to be contacted, please let us know, and we will remove your name from the list of follow-up study participants. However, we are hopeful that you will continue with this study, so that we can gain information that will be critical in developing plans to protect you and your community from this and other viruses that may emerge in the future.
We thank you in advance for your help
Dr. Glenn Morris and the UF Emerging Pathogens Institute study team
Please click on Next Page below to begin
Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText:
We very much appreciate your participation in the COVID-19 screening conducted at P.K. Yonge, in partnership with researchers at the University of Florida. The screening is being done as part of a research protocol, to allow us to gain a better understanding of why certain people become infected - and among those who are infected, for how long they are infected with the virus, even if they are asymptomatic. There is still a great deal that we do not know about COVID-19, and your continued participation in this study will be of great value as we try to learn how best to protect people from this virus.

As a starting point, we would like to ask you some basic questions about your child's health and possible exposures, as well as your current understanding of the virus, how it spreads, and what you are doing to reduce risk. We will also collect some information on how the current state of the pandemic is affecting you and your family in terms of stress and your current coping strategies. It will take about 20-30 minutes to complete the questionnaire, and all information obtained will be kept strictly confidential, as outlined in the consent form that you signed. We would then like to contact you again, in about 1 month, and again at 6 months and 1 year, to see how your child is doing, and if your child became ill during the intervening time period. This will help us to identify specific risk factors for infection or severe disease. If you would prefer not to be contacted, please let us know, and we will remove your name from the list of follow-up study participants. However, we are hopeful that you will continue with this study, so that we can gain information that will be critical in developing plans to protect you and your community from this and other viruses that may emerge in the future.

We thank you in advance for your help

Dr. Glenn Morris and the UF Emerging Pathogens Institute study team

Please click on Next Page below to begin

ItemDef.Name: qpk_sectiona
ItemDef.redcap:SectionHeader: SECTION A) ALL PARTICIPANTS, PARENT QUESTIONS (PARENTS COMPLETE THIS SECTION ONLY ONCE PER HOUSEHOLD)

Question.TranslatedText: We are going to ask you some questions about your household, including employment, your vaccination status, and your understanding of the COVID-19 situation. Have you answered these questions for another child in your household during this round of data collection (sometime in the past week)?
Click here to proceed to Section B:
Is any adult in your child's home currently employed?
For the adult with the most steady employment, is s/he part time or full time?
Does anyone in your child's home work or volunteer in a hospital or other medical setting?
If yes, where do they work/volunteer (enter all that apply)?
If not in a medical setting, where does the adult work or volunteer (enter all that apply)?
Has a primary wage earner within your child's household lost their job or regular income source due to COVID-19 at any point since March of 2020?
Is that person still out of work?

COVID-19 Parental knowledge, attitudes and practices Knowledge questions
For the following statements, please indicate if True or False.
Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText:
COVID-19 Parental knowledge, attitudes and practices

Knowledge questions

For the following statements, please indicate if True or False.

Question.TranslatedText: K1. The main clinical symptoms of COVID-19 are fever, fatigue, dry cough, and muscle aches.
K2. Unlike the common cold, stuffy nose, runny nose, and sneezing are less common in persons infected with the COVID-19 virus.
K3. There currently is no effective cure for COVID-19, but early symptomatic and supportive treatment can help most patients recover from the infection.
K4. Antibiotics can be used to treat COVID-19.
K5. Not all persons with COVID-19 will develop to severe cases.
K5. Not all persons with COVID-19 will develop to severe cases.
K6. People of all racial and ethnic groups can become infected with the COVID-19 virus.
K7. Most people who are infected with the COVID-19 virus recover from it.
K8. Handwashing can help reduce transmission of the COVID-19 virus.
K9. Persons with COVID-19 cannot pass the virus to others if they do not have symptoms.
K10. The COVID-19 virus spreads via respiratory droplets of infected individuals.
K11. Ordinary residents can wear general medical masks to prevent infection by the COVID-19 virus.
K12. It is not necessary for children and young adults to take measures to prevent infection by the COVID-19 virus.
K13. Isolation and treatment of people who are infected with the COVID-19 virus are effective ways to reduce the spread of the virus.
K14. People who have contact with someone infected with the COVID-19 virus should be immediately isolated in a proper place for 14 days.
K15. People with a strong immune system will not get infected with COVID-19.
K16. To prevent the infection by COVID-19, individuals should avoid going to crowded places such as restaurants, bars, concerts, etc.
Attitudes about COVID-19 For the following statements, please indicate how much you agree (Strongly disagree, Disagree, Neither agree nor disagree, Agree, Strongly agree)
A1. I am worried about getting infected with the COVID-19 virus.
A2. I feel confident I can prevent myself and my family from becoming infected with the COVID-19 virus.
A3. I know what actions to take to prevent myself and my family from becoming infected with the COVID-19 virus.
A4. I support CDC imposed guidelines for those who are infected with the COVID-19 virus.
A5. I support/would support city and state-imposed regulations to protect the public (e.g. business closures, mask wearing, park closures, beach closures, etc.)
A6. I support postponing or canceling mass gatherings such as concerts, festivals, and sporting events.
A7. I support closure of K-12 schools if any student, staff member, or teacher is found to have COVID-19.

A8. If I were exposed to and could possibly be infected with the COVID-19 virus, I would be willing to quarantine myself at home for 2 weeks until I was sure I was not infected in order to prevent others from getting COVID-19 from me.
A9. I support K-12 schools being open for in-person instruction.
A10. I am comfortable going out in public as long as I am in open spaces.
A11. I am comfortable going into essential public spaces as necessary, such as grocery stores, pharmacies, etc.
A12. I am comfortable going into public retail spaces, such as department stores, restaurants, etc.
A13. I think that the US government is handling the COVID-19 health crisis well.
A14. I support mask mandates in closed-in areas where physical distancing (6 ft) is not feasible (stores, offices, schools, etc.)
COVID-19 Practices For the following statements, please answer Yes or No.
P1. In recent days, I am washing my hands with soap and water more often than normal.
P2. In recent days, I am using more disinfectants, such as hand sanitizers and cloth wipes.
P3. In recent days, I am avoiding shaking hands or other physical contact with others outside my home.
P4. In recent days, I have adhered to social distancing guidelines, such as avoiding meetings of more than 10 people and keeping a distance of 6 feet apart.
P5. In recent days, I have bought larger amounts of staple foods (flour, sugar, pasta, rice, canned food) than normal.
P6. I am avoiding going into any crowded place.
P7. I wear a mask when leaving home and entering an indoor area with other people.
P8. In the past 7 days I have stayed at home or worked from home rather than going into work.
Q3) Total Family Annual Income (use 2019 estimate) $

PARENTS' STRESS and COPING MECHANISMS
In the past three weeks have you had the following feelings or thoughts? (Never, Occasionally, Half the Time, Often, Always)
Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText:
PARENTS' STRESS and COPING MECHANISMS


In the past three weeks have you had the following feelings or thoughts? (Never, Occasionally, Half the Time, Often, Always)

Question.TranslatedText: 1. I worry about many different things
2. I am irritable and have a short temper
3. I have unexplained physical ailments (headaches, digestive problems, dizziness)
4. I am having a hard time: sleeping, eating, interacting with others positively
V1. Do you plan on having your child(ren) vaccinated against COVID-19 (coronavirus/SARS-CoV-2) when a vaccine becomes available?
V2. How concerned are you that the coronavirus vaccine may not be safe for your child(ren)?
V3. How concerned are you that your child(ren) may have a serious side effect from the coronavirus vaccine?
V4. The information I receive about the coronavirus vaccine from the news/media is reliable and trustworthy.
V5. I am able to openly discuss my concerns about the coronavirus vaccine with my child(ren)'s doctor.
V6. The coronavirus vaccine will be effective at preventing COVID-19.
V7. Having my child(ren) vaccinated against the coronavirus is important for the health of others in my community.
1. Would you say in general that your health is:
2. Now thinking about your physical health, which includes physical illness and injury, for how many days during the past 30 days was your physical health not good?

ErrorMessage.TranslatedText: The value you provided is outside the suggested range. (0 - 30). This value is admissible, but you may wish to double check it.
The value you provided is outside the suggested range. (0 - 30). This value is admissible, but you may wish to double check it.

Question.TranslatedText: 3. Now thinking about your mental health, which includes stress, depression, and problems with emotions, for how many days during the past 30 days was your mental health not good?

ErrorMessage.TranslatedText: The value you provided is outside the suggested range. (0 - 30). This value is admissible, but you may wish to double check it.
The value you provided is outside the suggested range. (0 - 30). This value is admissible, but you may wish to double check it.

Question.TranslatedText: 4. During the past 30 days, for about how many days did poor physical or mental health keep you from doing your usual activities, such as self-care, work, or recreation?

ErrorMessage.TranslatedText: The value you provided is outside the suggested range. (0 - 30). This value is admissible, but you may wish to double check it.
The value you provided is outside the suggested range. (0 - 30). This value is admissible, but you may wish to double check it.

Question.TranslatedText: Optimism Response scale is the same for questions 1-10 below â¢ I agree a lot â¢ I agree a little â¢ I neither agree nor disagree â¢ I disagree a little â¢ I disagree a lot
1. In uncertain times, I usually expect the best.
2. It's easy for me to relax.
3. If something can go wrong for me, it will.
4. I'm always optimistic about my future.
5. I enjoy my friends a lot.
6. It's important for me to keep busy.
7. I hardly ever expect things to go my way.
8. I don't get upset too easily.
9. I rarely count on good things happening to me.
10. Overall, I expect more good things to happen to me than bad.
a) Close to me - Far away from me
b) Like it is spreading slowly - Like it is spreading fast
c) Like something I think about all the time - Like something I almost never think about
e) Media hyped - Not media hyped
f) Like something that makes me feel helpless - Like something I am able to combat with my own action
H3. How much do you trust information about COVID-19 from the following sources?
h) Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
i) Celebrities and social media influencers
l) US Government's National COVID-19 information website
H4. How often do you use the following sources for information about COVID-19?
h) Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
i) Celebrities and social media influencers
l) US Government's National COVID-19 information website
H5. How much confidence do you have that the following can handle the COVID-19 challenge well?
f) Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)
H6. Answer the questions below whether you agree or disagree.
a) I have a hard time making it through stressful events
b) It does not take me long to recover from a stressful event
c) It is hard for me to snap back when something bad happens
H8. Please indicate if you have:
a) Avoided people based on their ethnicity who I thought might infect me
b) Exercised less than I did before the pandemic
c) Drank more alcohol than I did before the pandemic
d) Ate more unhealthy food than I did before the pandemic
e) Smoked more than I did before the pandemic
f) Postponed vaccination for myself or my child
g) Avoided going to the doctor for a non-COVID-19-related problem
h) Bought drugs that I heard are good for treating COVID-19

F1. "We have relied on only a few kinds of low-cost food to feed our child/children because we were running out of money to buy food." Was that often, sometimes, or never true for your household in the last 6 months?
F2. "We couldn't feed our child/children a balanced meal, because we couldn't afford that." Was that often, sometimes, or never true for your household in the last 6 months?
F3. "Children in my house were not eating enough because we just couldn't afford enough food." Was that often, sometimes, or never true for (you/your household) in the last 6 months?

ItemDef.Name: qpk_f4
ItemDef.redcap:BranchingLogic: [qpk_skip3] <> '1' and ([qpk_f1] = '1' or [qpk_f1] = '2' or [qpk_f2] = '1' or [qpk_f2] = '2' or [qpk_f3] = '1' or [qpk_f3] = '2')

Question.TranslatedText: F4. In the last 6 months, since October 2020, did you ever cut the size of meals for a child in your house because there wasn't enough money for food?

ItemDef.Name: qpk_f5
ItemDef.redcap:BranchingLogic: [qpk_skip3] <> '1' and ([qpk_f1] = '1' or [qpk_f1] = '2' or [qpk_f2] = '1' or [qpk_f2] = '2' or [qpk_f3] = '1' or [qpk_f3] = '2')

Question.TranslatedText: F5. In the last 6 months, did a child in your house ever skip meals because there was not enough money for food?
F5a. How often did this happen-almost every month, some months but not every month, or in only 1 or 2 months?

ItemDef.Name: qpk_f6
ItemDef.redcap:BranchingLogic: [qpk_skip3] <> '1' and ([qpk_f1] = '1' or [qpk_f1] = '2' or [qpk_f2] = '1' or [qpk_f2] = '2' or [qpk_f3] = '1' or [qpk_f3] = '2')

Question.TranslatedText: F6. In the last 6 months, were any of your children ever hungry but you just couldn't afford more food?

ItemDef.Name: qpk_f7
ItemDef.redcap:BranchingLogic: [qpk_skip3] <> '1' and ([qpk_f1] = '1' or [qpk_f1] = '2' or [qpk_f2] = '1' or [qpk_f2] = '2' or [qpk_f3] = '1' or [qpk_f3] = '2')

Question.TranslatedText: 7. In the last 6 months, did any of your children ever not eat for a whole day because there wasn't enough money for food?

ItemDef.Name: qpk_q01
ItemDef.redcap:FieldNote: Note: your child may have been asked to isolate at home is s/he is a potential contact. Please indicate here the choice you indicated to PKY and where your child is registered as a student.

Question.TranslatedText: Q01. Is your child currently enrolled in in-person learning, where s/he is physically on PKY's campus in-person?
Q02. Has your child been engaged in school based sports this Spring?
Q03. Is your child currently in the school band?
Q04. Does your child have any of the following chronic illnesses?
Q04. Does your child have any of the following chronic illnesses?
Q04. Does your child have any of the following chronic illnesses?
Q04. Does your child have any of the following chronic illnesses?
Q04. Does your child have any of the following chronic illnesses?

Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText: Q05. Has your child ever received a flu vaccine?

Question.TranslatedText: Q06. Did your child receive the flu vaccine last year (Sept 2019-May2020)?
If yes, was it injection or nasal?
Q07. Was your child diagnosed with the flu last year (Sept 2019-May2020)?
Were they hospitalized for the flu?
Q08. Did your child receive the flu vaccine this year (Sept 2020-May2021)?
Do you plan on your child getting a flu vaccine (either injection or mist) this season?
Q10. Has your child had covid 19?
Q11. Including ongoing events, what is the number of times your child had a COVID-19 like illness since the last time a questionnaire was filled out (April, June, or October of 2020)?

Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText: Event 1:

Question.TranslatedText: Q11A. was a COVID-19 swab test (PCR) done?
Q11B. Was a COVID-19 antibody test done?
Q11C. Was an additional type of COVID-19 testing done other than a swab (PCR) or Antibody?
Q11E. Was care sought from a provider?
What type of provider was sought?

Q11G. Was a diagnosis of Toxic Shock made?
Q11H. Do you feel like your child's health is back to normal?
Q11J. Has your child been seen by his/her physician since resolution of the initial illness?

1. How many persons live in the child's household(s) in the period since the last questionnaire (in cases where the child lives between more than one household, please combine the number in both households)
1.A Between how many households does the child live?

2. Considering all of these household members, how many have been fully vaccinated for COVID-19 more than 2 weeks ago? (Fully vaccinated means that 14 days have passed after the last dose of the vaccine. If the vaccine was from Pfizer or Moderna, this would be 14 days after the second dose, if it was from Johnson & Johnson, this is 14 days after first and only dose)
3. Has anyone in the household been offered a COVID-19 vaccine and refused, or is eligible to sign up to get a COVID-19 vaccine and refused?
4. Has any member of the child's collective household had COVID-19 with or without lab confirmed test, or had a COVID-19-like viral syndrome of unknown cause?
5. Has anyone in the household died from COVID-19?
6. Has anyone in the family died from COVID-19?
For each deceased family member, list relationship to student.
CHILD STRESS and COPING MECHANISMS - In consultation with your child, please have him/her answer the following questions:
Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText: <font size=4><font color="red">CHILD STRESS and COPING MECHANISMS - In consultation with your child, please have him/her answer the following questions:</font>

Question.TranslatedText: CHILD STRESS and COPING MECHANISMS - Please allow your child to read and answer the following questions his/herself:
Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText: <font size=4><font color="red">CHILD STRESS and COPING MECHANISMS - Please allow your child to read and answer the following questions his/herself: </font>

Question.TranslatedText: In the past three weeks have you had the following feelings or thoughts? And if so, how often?
Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText: In the past three weeks have you had the following feelings or thoughts? And if so, how often?

Question.TranslatedText: 1. I feel hopeless and sad (about the virus)
2. I have trouble eating or sleeping
3. I find myself crying a lot
4. I feel worried or nervous (about the virus)
5. It is hard to stop my thoughts (about the virus)
6. I cannot stop worrying (about the virus)
7. I am very scared of getting dirty
8. I have to wash my hands, over and over to feel better
I0. It's hard for me to think a long time
Please ask and share your child's thoughts on the following questions:
Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText: <font size=4><font color="red">Please ask and share your child's thoughts on the following questions: </font>

Question.TranslatedText: Please share your thoughts on the following questions:
Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText: <font size=3>Please share your thoughts on the following questions: </font>

Question.TranslatedText: 1. What do you feel when you think of the virus?
2. How can you help yourself feel better?
3. How would you help a friend if they were feeling scared about the virus?
4. How is school helping you with the virus?
5. What else could help you with your feelings about the virus?
6. Would you like to read about ways to feel better about the virus?
Please allow your child to read and answer the following questions his/herself
Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText: <font size=4><font color="red">Please allow your child to read and answer the following questions his/herself</font>

Question.TranslatedText: In the past three weeks have you had the following feelings or thoughts?
Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText: <font size=3>In the past three weeks have you had the following feelings or thoughts?</font>

Question.TranslatedText: 1. Sadness, feeling down, low mood, feeling fatigued
2. Feelings of hopelessness, worthlessness, emptiness, or not being a good person
3. Decreased pleasure from things that used to be fun, feeling that life is not much fun
4. Feeling worried, nervous, panicky, tense, stressed out
5. Not being able to stop worrying or controlling your worry
6. Being easily annoyed or irritable, feelings of dread like something awful might happen
8. Fixation with washing your hands throughout the day
9. Sudden moments of fear or terror because you couldn't get rid of the germs
10. Felt a racing heart, shaky, sweaty, or had trouble breathing
Please share your thoughts about the following questions
Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText: <font size=3>Please share your thoughts about the following questions</font>

Question.TranslatedText: 1. If you feel stressed or scared about the coronavirus, what seems to help you feel better?
2. How do you help yourself feel calm when you hear about how the virus is spreading?
3. How do you help your friends that are feeling scared about the coronavirus?
4. What parts of school are helping you feel supported about your feelings about the coronavirus?
5. How does continuing to see your peers and teachers help you during this pandemic?
6. What types of handouts or readings would you be interested in about the coronavirus?

ItemDef.Name: nhh_date
ItemDef.redcap:SectionHeader: Thank you for participating as a household contact to a student participating in our COVID-19 study at P.K. Yonge. In the questions below "you" refers to the household contact. This may be you, or it may be an additional child in your household, such as a younger brother or sister of the participating student.

Question.TranslatedText: 3. Relationship to student participant(s) (parent, guardian, sibling (including step-sibling, half-sibling, etc.), aunt/uncle, grandparent, other)
6. Do you (household contact) identify as Hispanic or Latino? (Check only one)
7. Please check ALL racial descriptors that apply to you (household contact).
7. Please check ALL racial descriptors that apply to you (household contact).
7. Please check ALL racial descriptors that apply to you (household contact).
7. Please check ALL racial descriptors that apply to you (household contact).
7. Please check ALL racial descriptors that apply to you (household contact).

The value you provided is outside the suggested range. (0 - 30). This value is admissible, but you may wish to double check it.

Question.TranslatedText: 9. Have you (household contact) tested positive for SARS-CoV-2, been told by a health care provider that you were positive for COVID-19, or had positive antibody test for SARS-CoV-2?
10. Have you (household contact) been fully vaccinated against COVID-19? (For Pfizer and Moderna vaccines full vaccination requires two doses, for Johnson and Johnson one dose)
11. If yes, Which vaccine did you receive?
12. Do you know the date of your final vaccine dose?
In what month did you receive your final dose?

The following page will direct you to a scheduling interface where you can choose a time and date for COVID-19 testing at PK Yonge. Throat swab testing is what is currently used to quantify active viral infection. Additionally, we would like to obtain a small (four drops) blood sample to test for COVID-19 antibodies. The presence of antibodies to COVID-19 indicates that you have been in contact with the coronavirus that causes COVID-19. It does not indicate whether these antibodies are protective against future infection. However, our ability to study them will allow us to further understand the development of immunity.
Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText:
The following page will direct you to a scheduling interface where you can choose a time and date for COVID-19 testing at PK Yonge.
Throat swab testing is what is currently used to quantify active viral infection.
Additionally, we would like to obtain a small (four drops) blood sample to test for COVID-19 antibodies. The presence of antibodies to COVID-19 indicates that you have been in contact with the coronavirus that causes COVID-19. It does not indicate whether these antibodies are protective against future infection. However, our ability to study them will allow us to further understand the development of immunity.

Question.TranslatedText: Please select an appointment date and time

ItemDef.Name: research_encounter_id
ItemDef.redcap:FieldNote: This ID will be on each and every tube. It identifies a unique encounter with a unique person

Name of user who is calling the patient - 2nd attempt
Name of user who is calling the patient - final attempt
Date and time patient given positive results
Date letter was sent to subject
Name of user who sent the letter
Be sure to mark this form as Complete when the patient has been given their results or mailed a letter.
Question.redcap:FormattedTranslatedText: Be sure to mark this form as Complete when the patient has been given their results or mailed a letter.

CodeList.Name: qpk_race___0
CodeList.redcap:CheckboxChoices: 0, American Indian or Alaska Native -- a person having origins in any of the original peoples of North and South America (including Central America) and who maintains tribal affiliation or community attachment | 1, Asian -- a person having origins in any of the original peoples of the Far East, Southeast Asia, or the Indian subcontinent, e.g., Cambodia, China, India, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Pakistan, the Philippine Islands, Thailand, and Vietnam | 2, Black or African American -- a person having origins in any of the black racial groups of Africa | 3, Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander -- a person having origins in any of the original peoples of Hawaii, Guam, Samoa, or other Pacific Islands | 4, White -- a person having origins in any of the original peoples of Europe, the Middle East, or North Africa
